publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-1906 Mr Brian Monteith: Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling—That the Parliament recognises that it must investigate alternative temporary accommodation for May 2002 when the Church of Scotland is expected to require the use of the Assembly Hall for its General Assembly and calls upon the Parliamentary Bureau to consider Stirling as a potential location given its modern facilities, historic past, central location, excellent transport links and the fact that it has already hosted meetings of parliamentary committees.

S1M-1906 Mr Brian Monteith: Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling—That the Parliament recognises that it must investigate alternative temporary accommodation for May 2002 when the Church of Scotland is expected to require the use of the Assembly Hall for its General Assembly and calls upon the Parliamentary Bureau to consider Stirling as a potential location given its modern facilities, historic past, central location, excellent transport links and the fact that it has already hosted meetings of parliamentary committees.
S1M-1906 Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling (lodged on 3 May 2001) Cathy Peattie*

S1M-1906 Mr Brian Monteith: Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling—That the Parliament recognises that it must investigate alternative temporary accommodation for May 2002 when the Church of Scotland is expected to require the use of the Assembly Hall for its General Assembly and calls upon the Parliamentary Bureau to consider Stirling as a potential location given its modern facilities, historic past, central location, excellent transport links and the fact that it has already hosted meetings of parliamentary committees. Supported by: Cathy Peattie
S1M-1906 Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling (lodged on 3 May 2001) Mr Jamie McGrigor*

S1M-1906 Mr Brian Monteith: Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling—That the Parliament recognises that it must investigate alternative temporary accommodation for May 2002 when the Church of Scotland is expected to require the use of the Assembly Hall for its General Assembly and calls upon the Parliamentary Bureau to consider Stirling as a potential location given its modern facilities, historic past, central location, excellent transport links and the fact that it has already hosted meetings of parliamentary committees. Supported by: Cathy Peattie, Mr Jamie McGrigor

Supported by: Cathy Peattie, Mr Jamie McGrigor

Supported by: Cathy Peattie, Mr Jamie McGrigor
S1M-1906 Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling (lodged on 3 May 2001) Robin Harper*

S1M-1906 Mr Brian Monteith: Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling—That the Parliament recognises that it must investigate alternative temporary accommodation for May 2002 when the Church of Scotland is expected to require the use of the Assembly Hall for its General Assembly and calls upon the Parliamentary Bureau to consider Stirling as a potential location given its modern facilities, historic past, central location, excellent transport links and the fact that it has already hosted meetings of parliamentary committees. Supported by: Cathy Peattie, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Robin Harper
S1M-1906 Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling (lodged on 3 May 2001) Mr Keith Harding*

S1M-1906 Mr Brian Monteith: Holding Plenary Meetings of the Parliament in Stirling—That the Parliament recognises that it must investigate alternative temporary accommodation for May 2002 when the Church of Scotland is expected to require the use of the Assembly Hall for its General Assembly and calls upon the Parliamentary Bureau to consider Stirling as a potential location given its modern facilities, historic past, central location, excellent transport links and the fact that it has already hosted meetings of parliamentary committees. Supported by: Cathy Peattie, Mr Jamie McGrigor, Robin Harper, Mr Keith Harding
